LDCM Cloud Cover Assessment Update and Overview November, 2010
LDCM Cloud Cover Assessment
Update and Overview
November, 2010

Pat Scaramuzza, SGT U.S. Geological Survey Center for Earth Resources Observation and Science Sioux Falls, SD
Pat Scaramuzza, SGT
U.S. Geological Survey Center for Earth Resources Observation and Science
Sioux Falls, SD

U.S. Department of Interior
U.S. Department of Interior

Summary of LDCM CCA Changes in 2010
Summary of LDCM CCA Changes in 2010

• Minor changes to CCA Control flow.
• Minor changes to CCA Control flow.

– Thermal data switch, no saturation switch.
– Thermal data switch, no saturation switch.

• Using only non-saturated version of See5 CCA.
• Using only non-saturated version of See5 CCA.

• Quality Band format has been finalized.
• Quality Band format has been finalized.

• Creation of new ASTER dataset for thermal studies.
• Creation of new ASTER dataset for thermal studies.

– 15 ASTER scenes as both L1 (TOA reflectance) and L2 (kinetic
– 15 ASTER scenes as both L1 (TOA reflectance) and L2 (kinetic

temperature).
temperature).

• Addition of Thermal ACCA.
• Addition of Thermal ACCA.

– Using L7 ACCA on TIRS band 1. – Study using ASTER data suggests that surface temperature will offer no
– Using L7 ACCA on TIRS band 1.
– Study using ASTER data suggests that surface temperature will offer no

advantage over brightness temperature for the ACCA algorithm.
advantage over brightness temperature for the ACCA algorithm.

• Addition of Cirrus CCA.
• Addition of Cirrus CCA.

– Using 1.38 µm band threshold test from MODIS.
– Using 1.38 µm band threshold test from MODIS.

LDCM ACCA
LDCM ACCA

ACCA is a simple decision tree that does crude classification of land cover and clouds, then refines the cloud estimates using statistical data from the thermal band. It was developed by NASA Goddard for the Landsat program.
ACCA is a simple decision tree that
does crude classification of land cover
and clouds, then refines the cloud
estimates using statistical data from
the thermal band. It was developed by
NASA Goddard for the Landsat
program.

The LDCM ACCA algorithm is only the classification phase of ACCA, using TIRS thermal band 1.
The LDCM ACCA algorithm is only the
classification phase of ACCA, using
TIRS thermal band 1.

The snow/ice and water classifications reported by the ACCA algorithm will be provided in the Quality Band of the L1 product.
The snow/ice and water classifications
reported by the ACCA algorithm will be
provided in the Quality Band of the L1
product.

U.S. Department of Interior
U.S. Department of Interior

AT-ACCA
AT-ACCA

AT-ACCA is a variant of the ACCA algorithm that uses an 'artificial thermal' or AT band. This was developed as a means of running ACCA when thermal data is not available.
AT-ACCA is a variant of the ACCA algorithm that uses an 'artificial thermal' or AT band.
This was developed as a means of running ACCA when thermal data is not available.

The AT band formula was created using the Rulequest Cubist statistical modelling software as a combination of the reflective bands (Landsat bands 1-5 & 7). It was trained on 2 million pixels randomly selected from 103 Landsat 7 scenes, and it has an RMS Average Difference from actual Band 6 brightness temperature of 9.5 K.
The AT band formula was created using the Rulequest Cubist statistical modelling software
as a combination of the reflective bands (Landsat bands 1-5 & 7). It was trained on 2
million pixels randomly selected from 103 Landsat 7 scenes, and it has an RMS Average
Difference from actual Band 6 brightness temperature of 9.5 K.

To reduce the number of pixels markes as 'ambiguous' by the ACCA algorithm, a disambiguation algorithm was added to AT-ACCA. This is a small McCulloch-Pitts neural network organized in a voting scheme that can re-designate ambiguous pixels as either cloudy or clear terrain.
To reduce the number of pixels markes as 'ambiguous' by the ACCA algorithm, a
disambiguation algorithm was added to AT-ACCA. This is a small McCulloch-Pitts neural
network organized in a voting scheme that can re-designate ambiguous pixels as either
cloudy or clear terrain.

L7 Band 6
L7 Band 6

AT band
AT band

U.S. Department of Interior
U.S. Department of Interior

See5 CCA
See5 CCA

The See5 CCA algorithm was created using the Rulequest C5.0 stastical classifier software.
The See5 CCA algorithm was created using the
Rulequest C5.0 stastical classifier software.

The Rulequest C5.0 software creates a decision tree by finding the input variable which can best be divided by a threshold test. It selects the threshold value that minimizes the entropy in the dataset.
The Rulequest C5.0 software creates a decision
tree by finding the input variable which can best be
divided by a threshold test. It selects the threshold
value that minimizes the entropy in the dataset.

Once the dataset is divided into subsets, C5.0 then iterates over the subsets. It may select a different variable for each iteration. The user specifies how many iterations and what minimal amount of data each branch must contain. The end result is a decision tree of user-specified size.
Once the dataset is divided into subsets, C5.0
then iterates over the subsets. It may select a
different variable for each iteration. The user
specifies how many iterations and what minimal
amount of data each branch must contain. The
end result is a decision tree of user-specified size.

The LDCM See5 CCA decision tree has 245 branches, and was trained using 6.4 million pixels randomly selected from 104 Landsat 7 scenes.
The LDCM See5 CCA decision tree has 245
branches, and was trained using 6.4 million pixels
randomly selected from 104 Landsat 7 scenes.

U.S. Department of Interior
U.S. Department of Interior

LDCM Quality Band Format
LDCM Quality Band Format

The Quality Band for LDCM Level 1 products is a 16-bit image of the same dimensions as the L1G scene. Each pixel describes certain processing flags and land/cloud classifications.
The Quality Band for LDCM Level 1
products is a 16-bit image of the same
dimensions as the L1G scene. Each
pixel describes certain processing flags
and land/cloud classifications.

Cloud Datasets
Cloud Datasets

'Irish' Dataset – 212 Landsat 7 L1Gs scenes. (207 used) – Manual truth masks created by three analysts. – For general cloud studies. – Available online.
'Irish' Dataset
– 212 Landsat 7 L1Gs scenes. (207 used)
– Manual truth masks created by three analysts.
– For general cloud studies.
– Available online.

• Hyperion Dataset
• Hyperion Dataset • H y p e r i o n
D a t a s e t

– 22 Hyperion scenes, spectrally resampled to resemble Landsat 7 bands 1-5 & 7. – Manual truth masks created by a single analyst. – For studying Cirrus algorithms.
– 22 Hyperion scenes, spectrally resampled to resemble Landsat 7 bands 1-5 & 7.
– Manual truth masks created by a single analyst.
– For studying Cirrus algorithms.

• ASTER Dataset
• ASTER Dataset • A S T E R
D a t a s e t

– 15 ASTER scenes as both L1 (TOA reflectance) and L2 (kinetic temperature). – Manual truth masks created by a single analyst. – For studying brightness temperature / surface temperature differences in ACCA.
– 15 ASTER scenes as both L1 (TOA reflectance) and L2 (kinetic temperature).
– Manual truth masks created by a single analyst.
– For studying brightness temperature / surface temperature differences in ACCA.

Goddard / Rich Irish Test Data Set
Goddard / Rich Irish Test Data Set

212 Landsat 7 L1Gs scenes
212 Landsat 7 L1Gs scenes

– Provided by Rich Irish at NASA Goddard. – Divided by latitude into 9 zones, 20-24 scenes per zone. – Scenes acquired in 2000-2001. – When referring to 'Irish' in this presentation, we are referring to this data
– Provided by Rich Irish at NASA Goddard.
– Divided by latitude into 9 zones, 20-24 scenes per zone.
– Scenes acquired in 2000-2001.
– When referring to 'Irish' in this presentation, we are referring to this data

set. Ireland is not represented.
set. Ireland is not represented.

207 scenes with manual cloud masks
207 scenes with manual cloud masks

5 scenes were excluded due to visible gain change artifacts.
5 scenes were excluded due to visible gain change artifacts.

• One scene had a gain change but no visible artifacts; it was retained.
• One scene had a gain change but no visible artifacts; it was retained.

– Manual masks were created by three operators at EDC. – Cloud masks should be treated as having ~7% error.
– Manual masks were created by three operators at EDC.
– Cloud masks should be treated as having ~7% error.

• Based on 11 masks duplicated by all three operators.
• Based on 11 masks duplicated by all three operators.

Conclusions:
Conclusions:

• ASTER data does not make a good test set for ACCA.
• ASTER data does not make a good test set for ACCA.

– High number of ambiguous pixels suggest that spectral differences in Band 5 are the
– High number of ambiguous pixels suggest that spectral differences in Band 5 are the

problem in comparing ASTER to Landsat.
problem in comparing ASTER to Landsat.

• KT may have a slight (1.1%) advantage in classifying clear terrain, while BT may have a slight
• KT may have a slight (1.1%) advantage in classifying clear terrain, while BT may have a slight

(1.9%) advantage in classifying clouds.
(1.9%) advantage in classifying clouds.

• There is no clear advantage to using surface temperature in the ACCA algorithm. Brightness
• There is no clear advantage to using surface temperature in the ACCA algorithm. Brightness

temperature is as good (or slightly better), and is a less complex algorithm.
temperature is as good (or slightly better), and is a less complex algorithm.
